section.title: Using Symmetries of the Unit Circle
section.p: Earlier in this chapter, we defined the sine and cosine functions using a unit circle. The unit circle has many symmetries which help us find values of the circular functions. In this section we will explore those symmetries and relate them to the sine and cosine functions.

The circle x^2 + y^2 = 1 is symmetric about the origin and all lines that pass through the origin, including the x- and y-axes. Therefore, if the coordinates of one point on the circle are known, the coordinates of three other points can easily be determined. For example, the point P shown in has coordinates \left(a,b \right). Because of symmetry about the y-axis, the coordinates of point Q in the second quadrant are \left(a-,b \right). Because of symmetry about the origin, the coordinates of point R in the third quadrant are \left(-a,-b \right). Because of symmetry about the x-axis, the coordinates of point S in the fourth quadrant are \left(a,-b \right).

How does this symmetry relate to the circular functions? To explore this Question, suppose an arc of length s begins at \left(1, 0\right) and ends at point P. What length arc would terminate at Q? Since a person starting at \left(1, 0\right) can get to Q by walking \pi units in the counterclockwise direction followed by s units in the clockwise direction, an arc of length \pi-s will end at Q. Similarly, an arc of length \pi+s will end at R. Verify that an arc of length 2\pi-s and an arc of length -s will both end at S see .

section.p: The information in and can be combined with the definitions of sine and cosine to yield some important relationships. Recall that \sin \left(s \right) is equal to the y-coordinate of P and \cos \left(s \right) is equal to the x-coordinate of P. Since P and Q have the same y-coordinate, \sin \left(s \right) and \sin \left(\pi - s \right) are equal. Similarly, since P and S have the same x-coordinate, \cos \left(s \right), \cos \left(2\pi - s \right), and \cos \left(- s \right) are equal. Since P and R have opposite x-coordinates and opposite y-coordinates, \sin \left(\pi + s \right)=-\sin \left(s \right) and \cos \left(\pi + s \right)=-\cos \left(s \right). Each of these equations is an identity because each is true for all values of s.

statement.p: Suppose you know that \sin s = \frac{5}{13}. Find the exact values of \sin \left(\pi - s \right), \sin \left(\pi + s \right), and \cos \left(s \right).

solution.p: Due to the symmetry of the circle, arcs of length s and \pi - s have endpoints with the same y-coordinates, and therefore have the same sine value. Thus, \sin \left(\pi - s \right)=\frac{5}{13}. The endpoints of arcs of length s and \pi + s have opposite y-coordinates, and therefore have opposite values of sine. Thus \sin \left(\pi + s \right)=-\frac{5}{13}. There are two possible locations of the endpoints for arcs of length s: \pi - s and \pi + s. Since the sine of s is a positive number, s must end in either the first or second quadrant. If s ends in the first quadrant, then \pi - s ends in the second quadrant and \pi + s ends in the third quadrant which is shown in . If s ends in the second quadrant, then \pi - s ends in the first quadrant, and \pi + s ends in the fourth quadrant (shown in . Both of these possibilities are consistent with the fact that \sin \left(\pi - s \right) is positive and \sin \left(\pi + s \right) is negative.

solution.p: To find the values of \cos \left(s \right) we will use the fact that \sin \left(s \right) and \cos \left(s \right) are the y- and x-coordinates of a point on the unit circle, respectively, and \cos^2 \left(s \right)=1-\sin^2 \left(s \right). Since \sin \left(s \right)=\frac{5}{13}, we know that \cos^2 \left(s \right)=1-\left(\frac{5}{13} \right)^2, and therefore \cos \left(s \right) = \pm \sqrt {1 - \frac{25}{169}} = \pm \sqrt {\frac{144}{169}} = \pm \frac{12}{13}

In order to determine whether the cosine of s is positive or negative, we need to know whether s ends in the first or the second quadrant. Note that \pm \frac{12}{13} are exact values for \cos \left(s \right) and not decimal approximations. If decimal approximations are used, \sin \left(s \right) \approx 0.3846 and \cos \left(s \right) = \sqrt{1-\left(0.3846 \right)^2} \approx \pm 0.9231, which is not exactly equal to \pm \frac{12}{13}. Also, \left(0.3846 \right)^2+\left(0.9231 \right)^2 does not equal exactly 1. In many cases, decimal approximations are satisfactory; however, there are situations in which exact values are important.

statement.p: Suppose an arc of length L terminates in the second quadrant, and \sin L = 0.62 (see ). Find \sin \left(\pi - L \right), \cos L, and \tan \left(- L \right).

figure.caption: Arcs of Length s, \pi - s and \pi + s, in which \frac{\pi}{2} \lt s \lt \pi

solution.p: As before, we use the symmetry of the circle to recognize that L and \pi - L have the same sine. Thus >\sin \left(\pi - L \right)=0.62 Since \sin^2 \left(L \right)+\cos^2 \left(L \right)=1, we know that \cos \left(L \right)= \pm \sqrt{1 - \sin^2 \left(L \right)}. Now, L terminates in the second quadrant, so its cosine must be negative. Thus, we have \cos \left(L \right) = - \sqrt{1 - \left(0.62 \right)^2} \approx -0.7846 Since the tangent function is defined as \frac{\sin \left(L \right)}{\cos \left(L \right)}, we know that \tan \left(-L \right)=\frac{\sin \left(-L \right)}{\cos \left(-L \right)}. Recall that sine is an odd function, so \sin \left(-L \right)=-\sin \left(L \right), and cosine is an even function, so \cos \left(-L \right)=\cos \left(L \right). This means that tangent is also and odd function, since \tan \left(-L \right)=\frac{\sin \left(-L \right)}{\cos \left(-L \right)}=-\frac{\sin L}{\cos L}=-\tan \left(L \right). \tan \left(-L \right)=\frac{-\sin \left(L \right)}{\cos L} \approx \frac{-0.62}{-0.7846} \approx 0.7902
